children.name: expression
examples: ▪His expression became serious as he listened to her story.
Biểu hiện của anh ấy trở nên nghiêm túc khi anh lắng nghe câu chuyện của cô ta
expression of biểu hiện của
▪‘I’m not eating it,’ Maria said, with an expression of disgust on her face.
"Tôi sẽ không ăn," Maria nói với vẻ mặt ghê tởm.
wear an expression Đeo lên bộ mặt
have an expression
▪Wearing an expression of utter boredom, Harry turned back to his book.
Đeo lên một bộ mặt buồn chán, Harry quay lại với cuốn sách của mình.
expression on somebody’s face biểu hiện trên mặt ai đó
▪The expression on her face told me that she didn’t want to discuss it.
Biểu hiện trên khuôn mặt của cô nói với tôi rằng cô ấy không muốn thảo luận về nó.
expressionnounSHOWING nétmặt
[ C ] the look on someone's face, showing what they feel or think
_I could tell from her expression that something serious had happened.
_Mark always has such a miserable expression on his face.

children.name: look
children.definition: an expression on your face that shows what you are feeling: cái nhìn
examples: ▪She has a pensive, almost sad look about her.
Cô ấy có một cái nhìn đầy suy tư, dường như là buồn bã
look of cái nhìn của sự
▪A look of relief crossed his face.
Cái nhìn của sự khuây khoả hiện trên mặt anh ta
give somebody a look nhìn ai
▪ Sheila nodded and gave him a sympathetic look.
Sheila gật đầu và nhìn anh với vẻ đồng cảm.
a look of something on somebody’s face một cái nhìn với gì đó trên khuôn mặt ai đó
▪After winning, she had a look of pure joy on her face.
Sau khi chiến thắng, cô đã có một cái nhìn với niềm vui tinh khiết trên mặt.
the look on somebody’s face cái nhìn trên gương mặt ai đó
someone’s expression, especially an angry, shocked or disappointed expression
▪You should have seen the look on his face when I told him I was leaving.
Bạn nên nhìn thấy ánh nhìn trên khuôn mặt của anh ta khi tôi nói với anh ta rằng tôi sẽ rời đi.
look in somebody’s eyes nhìn vào mắt ai
▪Mrs. Moody had it in for me - I could tell by the look in her eyes.
Bà Moody đã đồng ý với tôi - tôi có thể nói với cái nhìn trong mắt cô ấy.
dirty look ánh mắt căm ghét
an expression of disapproval or anger
▪She’s been giving me dirty looks all morning. What have I done wrong?
Cô ấy đã cho tôi ảnh mắt căm ghét cả buổi sáng. Tôi đã làm gì sai?
wear a look trưng ra ánh nhìn
have a particular expression
▪He normally wore a slightly amused look on his round face.
Anh ấy thường trưng ra ánh nhìn vui vẻ trên khuôn mặt tròn của anh
looknounAPPEARANCE
[ C ] an expression on someone's face
_She had a worried look about her.
_Shegaveme a questioning look.

children.name: -faced
children.definition: showing a particular expression on your face: buồn
examples: sad-faced/grim-faced/solemn-faced khuôn mặt buồn/tồi tệ/trang nghiêm
▪A grim-faced doctor gave Marge the bad news.
Một bác sĩ với gương mặt tồi tệ đã đưa cho Marge tin xấu.
stony-faced/stone-faced/stern-faced mặt đá, mặt cứng đơ, mặt nghiêm khắc
with a very serious expression that shows little emotion
▪ Mr. Tanaka sat stone-faced, as if he could not hear the complaints.
Ông Tanaka ngồi xuống với khuôn mặt nghiêm túc, như thể ông không thể nghe thấy những lời phàn nàn.
straight-faced
without smiling, especially when you are lying or saying something funny
▪He told us straight-faced that he was thinking of running for president.
Ông ta nói với chúng tôi với khuôn mặt bình thản rằng ông đang nghĩ đến việc chạy đua cho tổng thống.
ashen-faced/gray-faced/white-faced khuôn mặt xanh xao, xám xịt, đỏ gay
looking very pale and upset, ill, or frightened
▪He returned from the meeting ashen-faced and shaken, saying he had to go home.
Anh trở lại từ cuộc gặp mặt với khuôn mặt xanh xao và đứng run run, nói rằng anh phải về nhà.
red-faced đỏ mặt
having a red face because you are embarrassed or angry
▪Myra still gets red-faced when she remembers the speech.
Myra vẫn còn đỏ mặt khi nhớ lại bài phát biểu.

children.name: a face that shows a lot of feeling
expressive
children.definition: showing very clearly what a person thinks or feels:
examples: diễn cảm
▪She is a wonderful actress, with striking, expressive features.
Cô ấy là một nữ diễn viên tuyệt vời, với những đặc điểm nổi bật và diễn cảm.
▪ He would use his expressive face to bring the stories to life.
Anh ấy sẽ sử dụng diễn cảm khuôn mặt của mình để diễn thật tốt câu chuyện
expressively[adverb]một cách biểu cảm
▪ Anthony said nothing, but rolled his eyes expressively.
Anthony không nói gì, nhưng cuộn tròn mắt một cách biểu cảm.
expressiveadjective truyền cảm
showing what someone thinks or feels
_an expressiveface
_expressivehands

children.name: mobile Umobile  British
children.definition: a mobile face is one that can change its expression quickly in a way that is attractive:

children.name: biến đổi nhanh
examples: ▪She has an extraordinarily mobile face and an infectiously comic manner.
Cô ấy có một khuôn mặt cực kỳ biến đổi nhanh và một phong cách truyền hình đầy tính truyền cảm.

children.name: to be very excited and enthusiastic
examples: _She was bubbling overwithexcitement/enthusiasm.

children.name: vent
children.definition: verblàm cho hả (giận), trút (tâm sự, nỗi niềm..)

children.name: to express a negative emotion in a forceful and often unfair way
examples: _Please don't shout - there's no need to vent yourfrustration/anger/rage/spleen onme.

children.name: give vent to sth
examples: to express a negative emotion in a forceful and often unfair way

children.name: to tell sb what you are feeling
express yourself
examples: make people understand what you are thinking or feeling
▪ Young children often find it difficult to express themselves in words.
express yourself
to communicate what you think or feel, by speaking or writing, or in some other way
_I'm afraid I'm not expressing myself very clearly.
_Children often express themselves in painting.

children.name: express
children.definition: to let someone know your feelings, by putting them into words:

children.name: bày tỏ, diễn tả ( cảm xúc thành lời )
examples: ▪ Ollie found it hard to express his feelings about the war.
▪ Parents have expressed concern about the amount of violence in some children’s shows.

children.name: get sth off your chest
children.definition: get something off your chest  to tell someone about something that has been worrying you or annoying you for a long time so that you feel better afterwards:
examples: ▪ I feel so much better now that I’ve got that off my chest.
▪ Writing to you is a good way to get things off my chest.
getsthoffyourchestinformal
to tell someone about something that has been worrying you or making you feel guilty for a long time
_I had spent two months worrying about it and I was glad to getitoff my chest.

children.name: pour out your heart/soul
children.definition: to tell someone everything about some strong emotions that you are feeling, especially feelings of unhappiness:
examples: ▪ Suddenly, Jason burst into tears and poured out his heart, telling his mother all about everything.
pour out your heart/soul to
▪ I had no idea Kay was so unhappy until she poured out her soul to me last night.
poursthoutphrasal verb[ M ]
to tell all your problems or feelings to someone, especially privately or secretly
_He spends every lunchtime pouring out his emotional problems to me and expects me to find a solution.

children.name: confide in
children.definition: to tell someone about something very private or secret, especially a personal problem, because you feel that you can trust them:
examples: ▪ He was a good listener and Elinor found it easy to confide in him.
confide in about
▪ He wanted desperately to confide in someone about his feelings of failure.
confide in that
▪ Harriet confided in me that she and Mark were considering divorce.
confide insbphrasal verbgiãi bày tâm sự với ai
to share your feelings and secrets with someone because you trust them not to tell other people
_She's nice, but I don't feel I can confide in her.
